Mark Johnson 246810121 246810121 C1A/3 ___________________________________________________
DATE OF CONSULTATION: May 24, 2024
CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Jessica Brown, M.D.
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Dr. James Wilson, M.D.
REQUESTING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Natalie Green, M.D.
GASTROENTEROLOGY
REASON FOR CONSULTATION Severe abdominal pain and bloating.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS This is a 55-year-old Caucasian man with a history of diverticulosis and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with severe lower abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. The pain has been persistent for the past three days and is not relieved by over-the-counter medications. He denies any vomiting, fever, or changes in bowel habits. He has been on a clear liquid diet since admission.
PAST MEDICAL & SURGICAL HISTORY 1. Diverticulosis. 2. Diabetes mellitus. 3. Hypertension. 4. Anemia. 5. Appendectomy.
FAMILY HISTORY His mother had a history of colorectal cancer. No other significant family history.
SOCIAL HISTORY The patient works as an accountant. He does not smoke and consumes alcohol occasionally. He is married and has two children.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS 1. Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. 2. Lisinopril 20 mg daily. 3. Iron supplements. 4. Ibuprofen as needed for pain.
LABORATORY DATA WBC count 12.0, hemoglobin 13.0, hematocrit 39.0, platelet count 220. Sodium 139, potassium 4.0, chloride 100, bicarbonate 24, BUN 15, creatinine 1.0. Blood glucose 180. CRP elevated at 12.5.
DIAGNOSTICS CT scan of the abdomen shows diverticulitis with localized abscess formation.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION VITALS: Blood pressure is 130/80, temperature 37.5, pulse 85, respiratory rate 18. HEENT: Normocephalic/atraumatic, no jaundice. ABDOMEN: Distended, tender in the lower quadrants, positive rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds present but hypoactive. EXTREMITIES: No edema. NEUROLOGIC: Alert and oriented, no focal deficits.
ASSESSMENT/RECOMMENDATIONS 1. Acute diverticulitis with abscess formation. a) Continue IV antibiotics. b) Surgical consultation for possible drainage. c) Maintain on a clear liquid diet and advance as tolerated.
2. Diabetes mellitus. a) Monitor blood glucose levels closely. b) Adjust insulin as needed.
3. Hypertension. a) Continue current antihypertensive regimen.
4. Anemia. a) Monitor hemoglobin levels. b) Continue iron supplements.
Thank you for the opportunity to assist in the care of this patient. Please contact us for any further assistance.
__________________________________ Dr. Jessica Brown, M.D.
